triples.name: Social influence
triples.relevance: The paper varies the strength of social influence in the artificial market to study its effects on inequality and unpredictability of success.

triples.name: Economic inequality
triples.relevance: The paper proposes that social influence increases inequality in cultural markets, showing how winners become disproportionately successful.

triples.name: Predictability
triples.relevance: The paper examines how success becomes increasingly unpredictable under varying levels of social influence, solving a central paradox about expert prediction failures.

triples.name: Hit song
triples.relevance: The paper studies hit songs as real-world examples of products with extreme success variation, motivating the artificial music market experiment.

triples.name: Music industry
triples.relevance: The paper creates an artificial music market to study how participants select and download previously unknown songs, directly inspired by music industry dynamics.

triples.name: Quality (business)
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes how product quality correlates with success, finding that quality is necessary but insufficient for market success.

triples.name: Experiment
triples.relevance: The paper proposes an experimental methodology using an artificial cultural market with 14,341 participants to investigate inequality and unpredictability.

triples.name: Prediction market
triples.relevance: The paper relates to prediction markets by investigating the difficulty of predicting successful products despite knowing their quality characteristics.
